unnormalised: Several NGOs based in Mumbai and Delhi are facing difficulties in collecting donations this year. A major reason cited is the rising inflation. Individuals who previously donated ₹500 monthly are now only able to donate ₹200 due to increased household expenses.
normalised: Several N-G-Os based in Mumbai and Delhi are facing difficulties in collecting donations this year. A major reason cited is the rising inflation. Individuals who previously donated rupee five hundred monthly are now only able to donate rupee two hundred due to increased household expenses.

unnormalised: "We've seen a significant drop of approximately 30% in online donations," stated Mr. Sharma, Director of 'Seva India,' a prominent charity. He further added, "While larger corporate donations are relatively stable, smaller individual contributions, which form a substantial part of our funding, have dwindled."
normalised: "We've seen a significant drop of approximately thirty percent in online donations," stated Mister Sharma, Director of 'Seva India,' a prominent charity. He further added, "While larger corporate donations are relatively stable, smaller individual contributions, which form a substantial part of our funding, have dwindled."

unnormalised: The 'Annadaan Foundation,' another NGO, highlighted that while the total number of donors has remained consistent, the average donation amount has decreased. "People are still willing to contribute, but their capacity has reduced," explained Ms. Khan, the foundation's spokesperson. "Instead of Rs. 1000, many are now donating Rs. 500 or even less."
normalised: The 'Annadaan Foundation,' another N-G-O, highlighted that while the total number of donors has remained consistent, the average donation amount has decreased. "People are still willing to contribute, but their capacity has reduced," explained Miss Khan, the foundation's spokesperson. "Instead of rupees one thousand, many are now donating rupees five hundred or even less."

unnormalised: This trend is impacting the operational capabilities of these charitable organizations. 'Asha Kiran,' a Delhi-based NGO focusing on child education, has had to scale back its programs by 15% because of the decreased funds. They've requested the government to offer tax exemptions of up to Rs 10000/- for charitable donations, as an incentive for people to donate more, so they can keep helping those in need.

unnormalised: Economists predict that this situation might continue in the short term. "As long as the CPI remains high, charitable giving will likely be affected," says Dr. Patel from the Indian Institute of Economics. He suggests that NGOs need to explore alternative funding models, like crowdfunding or partnering with local businesses to bridge the funding gap.
